Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Hey Folks,

I'd love to move away from an individual contributor role into strategy and at some point, a leadership role (Sr. Content Marketing Manager et al)

I have a few openings I'd like to apply for but I can't seem to find the best way to showcase my experience. 

I tried once and I was rejected due to a lack of experience. 

I have a blog post ranking on Google, a few happy clients, and I've taken all courses on Marketing from <http://DigitalMarketer.com|DigitalMarketer.com>. 

My past work has been with agencies so I don't have access to traffic stats and most content isn't under my name. 

Any idea (s) on how to present my resume / cv for such roles? Also, would any one be willing to provide feedback on my resume /cv once I create it? 

Thank you. 

"

Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Hi everyone,

The recent Superpath survey on test projects got me curious about:
1) how/if people have been able to negotiate pay or set more expectations around an interviewing test project and 
2) if anyone has ever declined moving forward with a test project because they felt the conditions were unfair (ex. work could be used by company, too arduous of a task for little or no compensation, etc)? 

As I am more junior in my career, I don't have the confidence that if I negotiate pay/more expectations, etc. that would yield positive results (when I have tried I've had mixed results, and have been burned anyways). Also, I feel so fortunate to receive interview offers that it's difficult to push back on the initial task outlined by the company (also being junior I wonder if I'm out of line with seeking compensation, asking for a shorter assignment, etc). 

Thank you so much for your time! "

Good companies _will_ pay you for test projects if they plan to use what you produce. (It may be more of an honorarium vs. market rate.)

In my experience, the reason a test project is arduous (and uncompensated) is usually because of internal chaos/lack of awareness vs. an intentional effort to take advantage of a candidate.

An HR rep or CMO or CEO may not realize what they're really asking of you.

I'd recommend this: Ask how long they want/expect you to spend on the project. They may time box it for you so that it's less work (e.g., "no more than two hours"), and if they have no idea or say something like "a day or two" or "as long as it takes," then you have a good opportunity to ask them to reflect on the ask they're making.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"How do I advocate for content on a greater marketing team that doesn't quite understand its impact or importance or doesn't seem to take me, the solo content marketer of the org, very seriously? 

There have been numerous occasions where I've felt my toes have been stepped on because I am seen as the blog channel manager, yet other teams will write blog posts without consulting with me beforehand, or I've proposed content ideas only for them to be shelved or given to someone else in the company to oversee. There have also been other members of the team managing important aspects of content (e.g. hiring an SEO agency) without my involvement. 

Does this sound like a lost cause? 
"

I feel bad being the first to jump in back-to-back on these, but since no one else has answered yet...

Let's be honest: It might very well be a lost cause. First, I think I'd try to parse:

1. Do they forget to ask for your input? Or
2. Do they not value your input?
Those are two very different things. If it's the first, there may be some opportunities for process improvement, but if it's the latter, I don't know what the solution would be.

That applies even if it's not valuing the input of _the person in your role_ (i.e. not specific to you). The single best indicator I've found of a content job being a good one is that the value of content marketing is understood throughout the organization.

That seems to happen most often when a business emerges out of, say, a blog; it's less common when a business is rolling and uses some spare cash to add content as a new channel.

The other thing that stuck out to me was that you're the blog channel manager but (1) others post without your knowledge, and (2) you don't get to publish your own ideas.

It seems like strategy—if there is one—lives with someone else, and your role is to execute work that's been delegated to you. That's not inherently bad, but it doesn't seem like their interpretation of your role is how you understand it or want it to be.
